results.title: Anger at work
results.creator_credit: Ned Huckman, International Film Bureau and Oaklahoma. State Dept. of Health
results.brief_description: Explains the mechanisms of man’s personality which induces displacement of anger onto other men and impairs efficiency in everyday living. Dramatizes techniques that have been developed for handling anger, resentment and frustration

results.title: Angel
results.creator_credit: Dennis K. Smith, Open Channel Productions and Sharyn Prentice
results.brief_description: You may not know the name Deborah Halpern, but you will certainly recognise her ceramic sculpture with its unique tiling located out the front of the National Gallery of Victoria. Hers is the story of a young ceramic sculptor with no formal training whose public profile has proliferated as the result of an unexpected major commission from one of Australia’s most prestigious art galleries. Deborah Haplpern’s art is inspired by Niki de Phalle, the ‘Art Brut’ movement and the ‘Outsider’ artists of Europe who live and work outside the mainstream gallery system. In this documentary Deborah talks intimately about the influence of these artists on her work and life. It outlines the structure of her sculpture, Angel, as well as the artistic and intellectual processes and motivation behind her work. This is a story of achievement. It is a passionate account of a two year project, the journey of a young artist and her triumphant arrival into the public art forum.

results.title: Andy Warhol and His Work
results.brief_description: This film is a fascinating insight into the man and his work as seen through his own eyes and those of his friends. As the sixties progressed Warhol became more and more involved in film making. A number of his films are classic examples of underground movie making and are valid reflections of the more extreme ends of life in late-sixties America.

results.title: Andy and the lion
results.brief_description: Story film for children. Uses the pictures and text of James Daugherty’s fantasy, based on the Androcles legend, to tell about an American boy who becomes a local hero when his kindness to an escaped lion is repaid with the lion’s friendship. No other credits available.

results.brief_description: A woman who feels neglected by her family on her 30th birthday has an affair with a man she meets that day only to find her family have organised a surprise party.

results.title: And yet it moves
results.brief_description: This film provides a look at how animators use their imagination; it also shows the materials they use. The film is divided into sections which show the creation of brief but effective story lines or commentaries in various media. Plasticine becomes a gracefully moving woman; another blob becomes a comic singer complete with cape; an egg revolves, bounces and catches fish.

results.title: And what about sugar ?
results.brief_description: This film glosses over the adverse effects of the consumption of sugar by implying that sugar is good for you in controlled doses, and that proper tooth care, rather than diet will prevent dental cavities. No other credits available.

results.title: And we're going. 4. To Toledo = I ya vamos. 4. A Toledo
results.creator_credit: Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Joshua Tree Productions
results.brief_description: A Spanish language film. Provides some cultural background of Spain and points out to the students the difference between Spanish spoken by Spanish Americans and Spanish spoken in Spain.

results.title: And then there was one
results.creator_credit: Eric Marquis, Oswald Skilbeck, Film Producers Guild and Verity Films
results.brief_description: Deals with the subject of depression, arguing that its symptoms are frequently overlooked. Illustrated with four examples: an overburdened salesman, a young mother unable to cope, a female factory worker with a repetitive job, and an older office worker whose symptoms are not recognised. Intended mainly for general practitioners. Written by Christine Netscher, photographed by Joe Ambor and edited by Ted Hunter. This film won the Silver Award (Category A) at the B.M.A film competition in 1966.

results.title: And then there was glass
results.brief_description: This documentary shows how glass is made. It gives an impression of the modern (1969) automatic machinery producing the molten material which is to be blown or pressed into the required shapes. It also shows the varied types of glass, and the uses to which they are put.
